children.subject: data100, cs188, history 100U (special topics course so it always changes, but lots of good choices there), nutrisci 10 (breadth)
I took CS 170 along with Math 53, EE 16B, and Nutrisci 10 (listed as NUSCTX 10).

history.content:
I mean it varies with what you're looking to do.

170 and 161 are probably important regardless of where in CS you work.

161 and 186 have decent project times, but are common for intro to upper div.

100 and 188 aren't too bad either and start the introduction into that whole AI/ML/data science field at Berkeley, although they are more focused on application than theory, unlike the others (imo)

126 and 127 are the core math courses required for a solid EECS math background as optimization and probability are used everywhere.

With all the hype around ML and the restructuring of 189, these classes got much more popular the last couple of years.

They do expect 70 and 16ab, respectively, so if you're L&S looking at 127 be wary and do your research

189 also assumes you have Math 53 (but mainly just the first half with the functions with vector inputs and output, along with the partial derivatives and gradients/jacobian),

so maybe take, or maybe self study

If you happen to also like EE like I do, 120 is a great place to start. 105 is the other core upper div, but I definitely found it painful

Beyond EECS, it's all up to you really. People like knocking out other requirements sometimes, but sometimes it could be fun to take other stuff. I've taken things like an intro neurosci class, plenty of language courses, wealth and poverty, special relativity, history of the civil rights movement, and a bunch of others. It's college. Great time to find out what you like and to explore and expand your mind and all that junk

Just wondering to see what other people took when they first started taking upper divs. Feel free to put any breadths that you took alongside that were p good too! I'm a sophomore going to be starting off with 170 and 127, for example (looking for a breadth).
history.subject: What were your first upperdiv CS classes?
